title: Over the Ocean; or, Sights and Scenes in Foreign Lands
author: Guild, Curtis
snippet: If the tourist has not previously learned that the Bear is the heraldicemblem of Berne, he will learn that fact before he has been in the citya quarter of an hour. Two granite bears guard the city gates; a shieldin the Corn Exchange is upheld by a pair of them, in wood; fountainshave their effigy carved upon the top; and in the cathedral square,keeping guard of a large bronze statue of a mounted knight in fullarmor, Rudolf von Erlach, are four huge fellows, the size of life, inbronze, at the four corners of the pedestal. Then the city governmentkeep a bears' den at the public expense--a huge circular pit, in whichthree or four living specimens of their tutelar deity solemnly promenadeor climb a pole for buns and biscuits from visitors.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: the Corn Exchange, a handsome and useful buildingrecently erected in the town, which, for the day,served as the refreshment room; and a capitalrefreshment room it made, being capable of accommodating two hundred persons comfortably at one time,and for several hours it was thronged with those forwhom it was intended.

title: Over the ocean;
author: Guild, Curtis
snippet: If the tourist has not previously learned that the Bear is the heraldic emblem of Berne, he will learn that fact before he has been in the city a quarter of an hour. Two granite bears guard the city gates ; a shield in the Corn Exchange is upheld by a pair of them, in wood ; fountains have their effigy carved upon the top ; and in the cathedral square, keeping guard of a large bronze statue of a mounted knight in full armor, Rudolf von Erlach, are four huge fellows, the size of life, in bronze, at the four coiners of the pedestal. Then the city government keep a bears' den at the public exj)ense — a huge circular pit, in which three or four living specimens of their tutelar deity solemnly promenade or climb a pole for buns and biscuits from visitors.

title: Seeing Europe with Famous Authors, Volume 2; Great Britain and Ireland, Part 2
author: Francis W. Halsey
snippet: Seamen cheering, herring-women bawling, coal-carts loading--the scene isanimated and lively. Yonder is the famous Corn Exchange; but the LordMayor is attending to his duties in Parliament, and little of note isgoing on. I had just passed his lordship's mansion in Dawson Street--aqueer old dirty brick house, with dumpy urns at each extremity, andlooking as if a story of it had been cut off--a rasée house.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: Our progress along the High Street was very slow, for there were so many interesting house fronts to examine. Mr. Fairfield could not pass the Corn Exchange or Watts' Charity, without some reference to their associations with Dickens ; nor could he pass the house opposite to the Post Office, without telling me that it was once Sir Richard Head's, and that through the garden behind, James II had stolen away to the river to embark for France, about a fortnight after he had dropped the Great Seal into the Thames at Lambeth. Even his determination not to refer to " Edwin Drood " was forgotten almost as soon as it was uttered.

title: An editor's retrospect;
author: Cooper, Charles Alfred
snippet: There were some incidents in the Campaigns of 1879 and 1880 which may not be so generally known. At one of Mr. Gladstone's meetings held in the Corn Exchange, Edinburgh, the late Earl of Airlie made a short speech in

title: Around the world :
author: Vanderslice, John
snippet: - Amsterdam is well supplied with all kinds of fish, sold very cheap, — a pair of large soles may be had for sixpence. I also visited the Corn Exchange, East India Warehouse, one-half of the building having sunk into the mud by the piles giving way, which causes the building to lean. I also went to see the dockyard and some charita-

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Further down, the foundation has just been laid of the City of Glasgow Bank, a building which will add another ornament to the city. In Hadden Street (off Market Street), is the Corn Exchange, a large new building with ample accommodation.

title: Sights and scenes in Europe :
author: Stevenson, William.
snippet: The Royal Mint, formerly in the Tower, is now on Tower Hill, and is quite a large building. Turning again towards St. Paul's I pass Mark Lane, with its Corn Exchange, and Mincing Lane, with its great Commercial  Salesroom, into Eastcheap, which leads me again to the statue of William IVth., at the head of King William street. By the way, this statue occupies the site of the ancient "Boar's Head Tavern in Eastcheap," made famous by Shakespeare  as the scene of Falstaff and Prince Henry's royster- ings, and where Falstaff drank such an "intolerable quantity of sack to but a haporth of bread."

title: Varieties in Prose
author: Allingham, William
snippet: flat affair. The Festival (tickets, one pound each) was inthe Corn Exchange, Grassmarket, a large area, decoratedwith blue and red calico and gaudy banners, in the styleof an infant-school feast. Two thousand people were saidto be present, and to most of them the speeches were inaudible.

title: Crusading with Knights templar under the banners of Allegheny commandery, no. 35,
author: Semple, David W. [from old catalog]
snippet: The Library is a new building  erected in 1827, and cost £20,000. But we must hastily pass over Stephen's Hospital, the Royal Hospital, the Corn Exchange, Linen Hall, Conciliation Hall, the

title: My first visit to Europe:
author: Dickinson, Andrew
snippet: It is a long road that never turns; but one without end is still longer ! There is an endless street in Paris — Rue de Viarmes. running round the Corn Exchange, a huge, famous stone building with a hemispherical roof.

title: A bachelor's rambles through the British Isles.
author: Butler, Charles J.
snippet: In the park I met a young man who had a strong desire to go to America, but I think before I left him I had convinced him he was better off in Ireland, for the present. At the Corn Exchange,

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: no hesitation in stating that the balance of comfort,economy, and pleasure, Was decidedly and largely infavour of the Temperance Eefreshment Booms* at theCorn Exchange.

title: Memoirs, journal, and correspondence of Thomas Moore.
author: Moore, Thomas
snippet: The * poet of all circles and the idol of his own ' has through his manly life never written one line tinged with a sectarian or unsocial spirit. The ascendancy on the one side, or the Corn Exchange upon the other, supplied him with no inspiration ; but true to the mind of his country and his own genius, he poured forth those strains which have been echoed by every class, and in every clime."

title: The footpath and highway:
author: Moran, Benjamin
snippet: At a meeting held at the Corn Exchange in the town on Friday  evening, June G, 1851, on the depressed state of the hosiery trade, a gentleman resident in Nottingham stated ^' that there were two hundred and fifty married men in the drawer and shirt business, destitute of employment, all of them with families of four persons on the average, each, which would make one thousand  persons in want of bread. With reference to the next branch, the ' cut-ups,' there were five hundred individuals out of work, none of whom had the means of procuring food, and putting them on the same average as the others, there were two thousand persons lacking the necessaries of life.

title: Crusading with Knights templar under the banners of Allegheny commandery, no. 35,
author: Semple, David W. [from old catalog]
snippet: We cannot possibly go over all the ground, the Royal Exchange, Corn Exchange, Coal Exchange, Blackfriars Bridge, the Temple, National Grallery, Ken-

title: Four years in Great Britain.
author: Colton, Calvin
snippet: Castle, Four Courts, Trinity College, St. George's Church, Blue Coat Hospital, Castle Chapel and Tower, Royal Exchange,  exterior and interior of the Metropolitan Chapel, Corn Exchange, Stamp-office, New Theatre Royal, Holmes' Hotel, College of Surgeons, Royal Dublin Society House, King's Inns, Lying-in Hospital and Rotunda, Linen Hall, St. Patrick's Cathedral, Nelson's Pillar, and the Wellington Testimonial — enclosing a draught of the city, embracing a circle whose diameter is two and a half miles.
